g.text: virtual bool allow_nested_vm_operations() const { return false; }
// You may override skip_thread_oop_barriers to return true if the operation
// does not access thread-private oops (including frames).
virtual bool skip_thread_oop_barriers() const { return false; }
// An operation can either be done inside a safepoint
// or concurrently with Java threads running.
virtual bool evaluate_at_safepoint() const { return true; }

font.div: // Roll all threads forward to a safepoint and suspend them all
// Arms the safepoint, _current_jni_active_count and _waiting_to_block must be set before.
// Will spin until all threads are safe.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // When returning from the native code, a Java thread must check

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // the safepoint _state to see if we must block. If the

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // VM thread sees a Java thread in native, it does

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // not wait for this thread to block. The order of the memory

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // writes and reads of both the safepoint state and the Java

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // threads state is critical. In order to guarantee that the

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // memory writes are serialized with respect to each other,

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // the VM thread issues a memory barrier instruction.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // Compiled code reads the local polling page that

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // is set to fault if we are trying to get to a safepoint.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // A thread which is blocked will not be allowed to return from the

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // block condition until the safepoint operation is complete.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // 5. In VM or Transitioning between states

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // If a Java thread is currently running in the VM or transitioning

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // between states, the safepointing code will poll the thread state

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // until the thread blocks itself when it attempts transitions to a

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // new state or locking a safepoint checked monitor.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // We must never miss a thread with correct safepoint id, so we must make sure we arm

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // the wait barrier for the next safepoint id/counter.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // Arming must be done after resetting _current_jni_active_count, _waiting_to_block.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // Threads might read this flag directly, without acquiring the Threads_lock:
// Number of threads we are waiting for to block:
// Counts the number of active critical natives during the safepoint:
// This counter is used for fast versions of jni_Get<Primitive>Field.
// An even value means there are no ongoing safepoint operations.
// The counter is incremented ONLY at the beginning and end of each
// A change in this counter or a change in the result of

// _wait_barrier, where they can quickly be started again.

switch.text: // JavaThreads that need to block for the safepoint will stop...

div.div: // An armed WaitBarrier prevents threads from advancing until the threads are
// woken by calling disarm(). The barrier is armed by setting a non-zero value
// - the tag. When the WaitBarrier is created, a thread is designated the owner
// and is the thread that should arm and disarm the WaitBarrier. In debug builds
// - After arm(tag) returns any thread calling wait(tag) will block.
// - Calling disarm() guarantees any thread calling or that has wait(tag) will
// return. Either they will see the WaitBarrier as disarmed or they will be
// unblocked and eligible to execute again when disarm() returns.
// - After calling disarm() the barrier is ready to be re-armed with a new tag.
// (may not be re-armed with last used tag)
// wait(tag); // don't execute following code unless 'safe'
// - A call to wait(tag) will block if the barrier is armed with the value
// - A blocked thread is eligible to execute again once the barrier is
// disarmed when disarm() has been called.

PosixSignals::pd_hotspot_signal_handler(int sig, siginfo_t* info,
ucontext_t* uc, JavaThread* thread) 🔗
{
...
os::Posix::ucontext_set_pc(uc, stub); // 直接修改 PC 寄存器，goto 跳到
SafepointBlob
...}

div.div:
Safepoint 协作流程可以划分为以下几步：
1. VM Thread 监听 Safepoint Request
2. 应用线程 Polling Safepoint
3. 一个应用线程 Request Safepoint
4. 接收 Safepoint Request
5. Arm Safepoint - 标记所有线程
6. 应用线程陷入 Safepoint
7. 等待所有应用线程到达 Safepoint
8. 执行 Stop The World 操作
9. Disarming Safepoint
10. 应用线程离开 Safepoint

switch.text: Safepoint 协作流程可以划分为以下几步：...
